entities.description: Daniel Heinsius was one of the most famous scholars of the Dutch Renaissance.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alessandro Stradella, Italian composer (b. 1639)

entities.title: Alessandro Stradella
entities.description: Antonio Alessandro Boncompagno Stradella was an Italian composer of the middle Baroque period. He enjoyed a dazzling career as a freelance composer, writing on commission, and collaborating with distinguished poets, producing over three hundred works in a variety of genres.

heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel Greysolon, Sieur du Lhut, French soldier and explorer (b. 1639)

entities.title: Daniel Greysolon, Sieur du Lhut
entities.description: Daniel Greysolon, Sieur du Lhut was a French soldier and explorer who is the first European known to have visited the area where the city of Duluth, Minnesota, is now located and the headwaters of the Mississippi River near Bemidji, Minnesota. His name is sometimes anglicized as "DuLuth", and he is the namesake of Duluth, Minnesota, as well as Duluth, Georgia. Daniel Greysolon signed himself "Dulh

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick I of Prussia (b. 1657)

entities.title: Frederick I of Prussia
entities.description: Frederick I, of the Hohenzollern dynasty, was Elector of Brandenburg (1688–1713) and Duke of Prussia in personal union (Brandenburg-Prussia). The latter function he upgraded to royalty, becoming the first King in Prussia (1701–1713). From 1707 he was in personal union the sovereign prince of the Principality of Neuchâtel. He was also the paternal grandfather of Frederick the Great.

heading: Deaths
txt: Christopher Wren, English architect, designed St Paul's Cathedral (b. 1632)

entities.title: Christopher Wren
entities.description: Sir Christopher Wren PRS FRS was one of the most highly acclaimed English architects in history, as well as an anatomist, astronomer, geometer, and mathematician-physicist. He was accorded responsibility for rebuilding 52 churches in the City of London after the Great Fire in 1666, including what is regarded as his masterpiece, St Paul's Cathedral, on Ludgate Hill, completed in 1710.

entities.title: St Paul's Cathedral
entities.description: St Paul's Cathedral is an Anglican cathedral in London, United Kingdom, which, as the cathedral of the Bishop of London, serves as the mother church of the Diocese of London. It sits on Ludgate Hill at the highest point of the City of London and is a Grade I listed building. Its dedication to Paul the Apostle dates back to the original church on this site, founded in AD 604. The present cathedral,

heading: Deaths
txt: Eliza Haywood, English actress and poet (b. 1693)

entities.title: Eliza Haywood
entities.description: Eliza Haywood, born Elizabeth Fowler, was an English writer, actress and publisher. An increase in interest and recognition of Haywood's literary works began in the 1980s. Described as "prolific even by the standards of a prolific age", Haywood wrote and published over seventy works during her lifetime including fiction, drama, translations, poetry, conduct literature and periodicals. Haywood is a

heading: Deaths
txt: Samuel Seabury, American bishop (b. 1729)

entities.title: Samuel Seabury (bishop)
entities.description: Samuel Seabury was the first American Episcopal bishop, the second Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America, and the first Bishop of Connecticut. He was a leading Loyalist in New York City during the American Revolution, a known rival of Alexander Hamilton, and an enslaver.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Pownall, English politician, Governor of the Province of Massachusetts Bay (b. 1722)

entities.title: Thomas Pownall
entities.description: Thomas Pownall was a British colonial official and politician. He was governor of the Province of Massachusetts Bay from 1757 to 1760, and afterwards sat in the House of Commons from 1767 to 1780. He travelled widely in the North American colonies prior to the American Revolutionary War, opposed Parliamentary attempts to tax the colonies, and was a minority advocate of colonial positions until the

entities.title: Governor of the Province of Massachusetts Bay
entities.description: The territory of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, one of the fifty United States, was settled in the 17th century by several different English colonies. The territories claimed or administered by these colonies encompassed a much larger area than that of the modern state, and at times included areas that are now within the jurisdiction of other New England states or of the Canadian provinces of

heading: Deaths
txt: Francisco Manoel de Nascimento, Portuguese-French poet and educator (b. 1734)

entities.title: Francisco Manoel de Nascimento
entities.description: Francisco Manoel de Nascimento, Portuguese poet, better known by the literary name of Filinto Elísio, bestowed on him by the Marquise of Alorna, was the reputed son of a Lisbon boat-owner.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Pinkney, American politician and diplomat, 7th United States Attorney General (b. 1764)

entities.title: William Pinkney
entities.description: William Pinkney was an American statesman and diplomat, and was appointed the seventh U.S. Attorney General by President James Madison.

entities.title: United States Attorney General
entities.description: The United States attorney general (AG) leads the United States Department of Justice, and is the chief lawyer of the federal government of the United States. The attorney general serves as the principal advisor to the president of the United States on all legal matters. The attorney general is a statutory member of the Cabinet of the United States.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip P. Barbour, American lawyer, judge, and politician, 12th Speaker of the United States House of Representatives (b. 1783)

entities.title: Philip P. Barbour
entities.description: Philip Pendleton Barbour was the tenth Speaker of the United States House of Representatives and an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. He is the only individual to serve in both positions.

entities.title: Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
entities.description: The speaker of the United States House of Representatives, commonly known as the Speaker of the House, is the presiding officer of the United States House of Representatives. The office was established in 1789 by Article I, Section 2 of the U.S. Constitution. The speaker is the political and parliamentary leader of the House of Representatives and is simultaneously the House's presiding officer, d

heading: Deaths
txt: Daoguang Emperor of China (b. 1782)

entities.title: Daoguang Emperor
entities.description: The Daoguang Emperor was the seventh Emperor of the Qing dynasty, and the sixth Qing emperor to rule over China proper, reigning from 1820 to 1850. His reign was marked by "external disaster and internal rebellion," that is, by the First Opium War, and the beginning of the Taiping Rebellion which nearly brought down the dynasty. The historian Jonathan Spence characterizes the Daoguang Emperor as a

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Moore, Irish poet and lyricist (b. 1779)

entities.title: Thomas Moore
entities.description: Thomas Moore was an Irish writer, poet and lyricist celebrated for his Irish Melodies. Their setting of English-language verse to old Irish tunes marked the transition in popular Irish culture from Irish to English. Politically, Moore was recognised in England as a press, or "squib", writer for the aristocratic Whigs; in Ireland he was accounted a Catholic patriot. Married to a Protestant actress

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Ludwig, German author, playwright, and critic (b. 1813)

entities.title: Otto Ludwig (writer)
entities.description: Otto Ludwig was a German dramatist, novelist and critic born in Eisfeld in Thuringia. He was one of Germany's first modern realists and one of the most notable dramatists of the period.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henrik Hertz, Danish poet and playwright (b. 1797)

entities.title: Henrik Hertz
entities.description: Henrik Hertz was a Danish poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jung Bahadur Rana, Nepalese ruler (b. 1816)

entities.title: Jung Bahadur Rana
entities.description: Maharaja Jung Bahadur Kunwar Ranaji, was a Khas Rajput (Chhetri) ruler of Nepal and founder of the Rana Regime in Nepal. Jung Bahadur took control of the government after killing an alleged usurper, Gagan Singh, who was accused of plotting with the junior queen in 1846 to become prime minister by putting the queen's son on the throne. His original name was Bir Narsingh Kunwar but he was popularly

heading: Deaths
txt: Townsend Harris, American merchant, politician, and diplomat, United States Ambassador to Japan (b. 1804)

entities.title: Townsend Harris
entities.description: Townsend Harris was an American merchant and minor politician, and the first United States Consul General to Japan. He negotiated the "Harris Treaty" between the US and Japan and is credited as the diplomat who first opened Shogunate Japan to foreign trade and culture in the Edo period.

entities.title: United States Ambassador to Japan
entities.description: The Ambassador of the United States of America to Japan  is the ambassador from the United States of America to Japan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Reuter, German-English journalist and businessman, founded Reuters (b. 1816)

entities.title: Paul Reuter
entities.description: Paul Julius Reuter, later titled as Freiherr von Reuter, was a German-born British entrepreneur who was a pioneer of telegraphy and news reporting. He was a reporter and media owner, and the founder of Reuters news agency, which became part of the Thomson Reuters conglomerate in 2008.

entities.title: Reuters
entities.description: Reuters is an international news organisation owned by Thomson Reuters. It employs around 2,500 journalists and 600 photojournalists in about 200 locations worldwide. Reuters is one of the largest news agencies in the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anton Arensky, Russian pianist and composer (b. 1861)

entities.title: Anton Arensky
entities.description: Anton Stepanovich Arensky was a Russian composer of Romantic classical music, a pianist and a professor of music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Worthington Whittredge, American painter and educator (b. 1820)

entities.title: Worthington Whittredge
entities.description: Thomas Worthington Whittredge was an American artist of the Hudson River School. Whittredge was a highly regarded artist of his time, and was friends with several leading Hudson River School artists including Albert Bierstadt and Sanford Robinson Gifford. He traveled widely and excelled at landscape painting, many examples of which are now in major museums. He served as president of the National A

heading: Deaths
txt: Friedrich Spielhagen, German author, theorist, and translator (b. 1829)

entities.title: Friedrich Spielhagen
entities.description: Friedrich Spielhagen was a German novelist, literary theorist and translator. He tried a number of careers in his early 20s, but at 25 began writing and translating. His best known novel is Sturmflut and his novel In Reih' und Glied was quite successful in Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: William IV, Grand Duke of Luxembourg (b. 1852)

entities.title: William IV, Grand Duke of Luxembourg
entities.description: William IV reigned as the Grand Duke of Luxembourg from 17 November 1905 until his death. He succeeded his father, Adolphe.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Tenniel, English illustrator (b. 1820)

entities.title: John Tenniel
entities.description: Sir John Tenniel was an English illustrator, graphic humorist and political cartoonist prominent in the second half of the 19th century. He was knighted for artistic achievements in 1893. Tenniel is remembered mainly as the principal political cartoonist for Punch magazine for over 50 years and for his illustrations to Lewis Carroll's Alice's Adventures in Wonderland (1865) and Through the Looking

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Edwin Bessey, American botanist, author, and academic (b. 1845)

entities.title: Charles Edwin Bessey
entities.description: Charles Edwin Bessey was an American botanist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marcel-Auguste Dieulafoy, French archaeologist and engineer (b. 1844)

entities.title: Marcel-Auguste Dieulafoy
entities.description: Marcel-Auguste Dieulafoy was a French archaeologist, noted for his excavations at Susa in 1885 and for his work, L'Art antique de la Perse.

heading: Deaths
txt: William O'Brien, Irish journalist and politician (b. 1852)

entities.title: William O'Brien
entities.description: William O'Brien was an Irish nationalist, journalist, agrarian agitator, social revolutionary, politician, party leader, newspaper publisher, author and Member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. He was particularly associated with the campaigns for land reform in Ireland during the late 19th and early 20th centuries as well as his concili

heading: Deaths
txt: Elizabeth Gertrude Britton, American botanist and academic (b. 1857)

entities.title: Elizabeth Gertrude Britton
entities.description: Elizabeth Gertrude Britton was an American botanist, bryologist, and educator. She and her husband, Nathaniel Lord Britton played a significant role in the fundraising and creation of the New York Botanical Garden. She was a co-founder of the predecessor to the American Bryological and Lichenological Society. She was an activist for protection of wildflowers, inspiring local chapter activities and

heading: Deaths
txt: John McGraw, American baseball player and manager (b. 1873)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mário de Andrade, Brazilian author, poet, and photographer (b. 1893)

entities.title: Mário de Andrade
entities.description: Mário Raul de Morais Andrade was a Brazilian poet, novelist, musicologist, art historian and critic, and photographer. One of the founders of Brazilian modernism, he virtually created modern Brazilian poetry with the publication of his Paulicéia Desvairada in 1922. He has had an enormous influence on modern Brazilian literature, and as a scholar and essayist—he was a pioneer of the field of ethnom

heading: Deaths
txt: George Minot, American physician and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1885)

entities.title: George Minot
entities.description: George Richards Minot was an American medical researcher who shared the 1934 Nobel Prize with George Hoyt Whipple and William P. Murphy for their pioneering work on pernicious anemia.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sergei Winogradsky, Ukrainian-Russian microbiologist and ecologist (b. 1856)

entities.title: Sergei Winogradsky
entities.description: Sergei Nikolaievich Winogradsky was a Russian microbiologist, ecologist and soil scientist who pioneered the cycle-of-life concept.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mark Aldanov, Russian author and critic (b. 1888)

entities.title: Mark Aldanov
entities.description: Mark Aldanov was a Russian Empire and later French writer and critic, known for his historical novels.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bugs Moran, American mob boss (b. 1893)

heading: Deaths
txt: Melville J. Herskovits, American anthropologist and academic (b. 1895)

entities.title: Melville J. Herskovits
entities.description: Melville Jean Herskovits was an American anthropologist who helped establish African and African-American studies in American academia. He is known for exploring the cultural continuity from African cultures as expressed in African-American communities. He worked with his wife Frances (Shapiro) Herskovits, also an anthropologist, in the field in South America, the Caribbean and Africa. They jointl

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Archipenko, Ukrainian sculptor and illustrator (b. 1887)

entities.title: Alexander Archipenko
entities.description: Alexander Porfyrovych Archipenko was a Ukrainian and American avant-garde artist, sculptor, and graphic artist. He was one of the first to apply the principles of Cubism to architecture, analyzing human figure into geometrical forms.

heading: Deaths
txt: Grace Metalious, American author (b. 1924)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mark Rothko, Latvian-American painter and academic (b. 1903)

entities.title: Mark Rothko
entities.description: Mark Rothko, born Markus Yakovlevich Rothkowitz, , was an American abstract painter of Latvian Jewish descent. He is best known for his color field paintings that depicted irregular and painterly rectangular regions of color, which he produced from 1949 to 1970.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theodor Svedberg, Swedish chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1884)

entities.title: Theodor Svedberg
entities.description: Theodor ("The") Svedberg was a Swedish chemist and Nobel laureate for his research on colloids and proteins using the ultracentrifuge. Svedberg was active at Uppsala University from the mid 1900s to late 1940s. While at Uppsala, Svedberg started as a docent before becoming the university's physical chemistry head in 1912. After leaving Uppsala in 1949, Svedberg was in charge of the Gustaf Werner I

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Gottfried Fuchs, German-Canadian Olympic soccer player (b. 1889)

entities.title: Gottfried Fuchs
entities.description: Gottfried Erik Fuchs (also Godfrey Fuchs; was a German Olympic footballer. He scored a then-world record 10 goals for the Germany national football team in a 16–0 win against Russia at the 1912 Olympics. He left Germany to escape the Holocaust, as he was Jewish, and ultimately emigrated to Canada.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elijah Muhammad, American religious leader (b. 1897)

entities.title: Elijah Muhammad
entities.description: Elijah Muhammad was a religious leader and author who led the Nation of Islam (NOI) from 1934 until his death in 1975, and he claimed that he is The Messenger of Allah (God), to the Nation of Islam believers. Muhammad was also the teacher and mentor of Malcolm X, Louis Farrakhan, Muhammad Ali, and his own son, Warith Deen Mohammed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel James, Jr., American general and pilot (b. 1920)

entities.title: Daniel James, Jr.
entities.description: Daniel "Chappie" James Jr. was a fighter pilot in the United States Air Force who, in 1975, became the first African American to reach the rank of four-star general in the United States Armed Forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Hayden, American poet and academic (b. 1913)

entities.title: Robert Hayden
entities.description: Robert Hayden was an American poet, essayist, and educator. He served as Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress from 1976 to 1978, a role today known as US Poet Laureate. He was the first African-American writer to hold the office.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tennessee Williams, American playwright, and poet (b. 1911)

entities.title: Tennessee Williams
entities.description: Thomas Lanier Williams III, known by his pen name Tennessee Williams, was an American playwright. Along with contemporaries Eugene O'Neill and Arthur Miller, he is considered among the three foremost playwrights of 20th-century American drama.

heading: Deaths
txt: Haing S. Ngor, Cambodian-American physician and author (b. 1940)

entities.title: Haing S. Ngor
entities.description: Haing Somnang Ngor was a Cambodian American gynecologist, obstetrician, actor and author. He is best remembered for winning the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor in 1985 for his debut performance in the film The Killing Fields (1984), in which he portrayed Cambodian journalist and refugee Dith Pran. He was murdered in a robbery outside his home in Los Angeles in 1996.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrei Sinyavsky, Russian journalist and publisher (b. 1925)

entities.title: Andrei Sinyavsky
entities.description: Andrei Donatovich Sinyavsky was a Russian writer and Soviet dissident known as a defendant in the Sinyavsky–Daniel trial in 1965.

heading: Deaths
txt: W. O. Mitchell, Canadian author and playwright (b. 1914)

entities.title: W. O. Mitchell
entities.description: William Ormond Mitchell, better known as W. O. Mitchell was a Canadian writer and broadcaster. His "best-loved" novel is Who Has Seen the Wind (1947), which portrays life on the Canadian Prairies and sold almost a million copies in Canada. As a broadcaster, he is known for his radio series Jake and the Kid, which aired on CBC Radio between 1950 and 1956 and was also about life on the Prairies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Glenn T. Seaborg, American chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1912)

entities.title: Glenn T. Seaborg
entities.description: Glenn Theodore Seaborg was an American chemist whose involvement in the synthesis, discovery and investigation of ten transuranium elements earned him a share of the 1951 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. His work in this area also led to his development of the actinide concept and the arrangement of the actinide series in the periodic table of the elements.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: A. R. Ammons, American poet and critic (b. 1926)

entities.title: A. R. Ammons
entities.description: Archie Randolph Ammons was an American poet who won the annual National Book Award for Poetry in 1973 and 1993.

heading: Deaths
txt: Don Bradman, Australian international cricketer; holder of world record batting average (b. 1908)

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Benenson, English lawyer, founded Amnesty International (b. 1921)

entities.title: Peter Benenson
entities.description: Peter Benenson was a British lawyer, human rights activist and the founder of human rights group Amnesty International (AI). He refused all honours, but in his 80s, largely to please his family, he accepted the Pride of Britain Award for Lifetime Achievement in 2001.

entities.title: Amnesty International
entities.description: Amnesty International is an international non-governmental organization with its headquarters in the United Kingdom focused on human rights. The organization says it has more than seven million members and supporters around the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Raj Khanna, Indian judge and advocate; upholder of civil liberties (b. 1912)

entities.title: Hans Raj Khanna
entities.description: Hans Raj Khanna was an Indian judge, jurist and advocate who propounded the basic structure doctrine in 1973 and upheld civil liberties during the time of Emergency in India in a lone dissenting judgement in 1976. He entered the Indian judiciary in 1952 as an Additional District and Sessions Judge and subsequently was elevated as a judge to the Supreme Court of India in 1971 where he continued til

heading: Deaths
txt: Ihsan Dogramaci, Turkish pediatrician and academic (b. 1915)

entities.title: Ihsan Dogramaci
entities.description: Professor İhsan Doğramacı was a Turkish paediatrician, entrepreneur, philanthropist, educationalist and college administrator of Iraqi Turkmen descent born in Arbil, Iraq, then Ottoman Empire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louisiana Red, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1932)

entities.title: Louisiana Red
entities.description: Iverson Minter, known as Louisiana Red, was an American blues guitarist, harmonica player, and singer, who recorded more than 50 albums. He was best known for his song "Sweet Blood Call".

heading: Deaths
txt: Harve Bennett, American screenwriter and producer (b. 1930)

entities.title: Harve Bennett
entities.description: Harve Bennett was an American television and film producer and screenwriter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eugenie Clark, American biologist and academic; noted ichthyologist (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dmitry Yazov, last Marshal of the Soviet Union (b. 1924)

entities.title: Dmitry Yazov
entities.description: Dmitry Timofeyevich Yazov was the last Marshal of the Soviet Union, appointed to that rank on 28 April 1990, and was the only Marshal born in Siberia. A veteran of the Great Patriotic War, Yazov served as Minister of Defence from 1987 until he was arrested for his part in the 1991 August Coup, four months before the fall of the Soviet Union.

entities.title: Marshal of the Soviet Union
entities.description: Marshal of the Soviet Union was the highest military rank of the Soviet Union.
